Cast Map¶

SomeToken as S := 'abc';
Alpha          := R'[a-z]+';
F ::= S'abc' | Alpha;

The ruiko codes above defines a tokenize named SomeToken with a prefix S.

When the input source is splitted into a series of Tokenizers , however, even the literal parser Alpha is supposed to match all string matched by regex pattern "[a-z]+", it cannot match a tokenizer with string "abc" generated by EBNFParser automatical tokenizing, that’s because all the "all" has been casted into a unique string in a buffer pool, and all of them have the same name SomeToken, not Alpha.

Here is a string with value "abc" with an unique memory address, and every literal parser defined by "abc" just matched it only.

The literal parser defined as Alpha := R'[a-z]+' just matches the tokenizer whose name is Alpha.

Prefix¶

If you’re using custom tokenizing, several Tokenizer object with the same string “abc”(and have the same memory address) could have different names.

To distinguish from each other, you can do as the following:

  • Grammar
SomeToken as S := 'abc';
Alpha          := R'[a-z]+';
F ::= S'abc' | Alpha;
G ::= 'abc';
H ::= G | F ;

Tokenizers:
    [name: SomeToken, string: "abc"]
    ...

If you are using combined parser G to match these tokenizers, you’ll fail, because in the grammar G is defined as G::='abc' , it means G only accepts the a tokenizer who has an attribute name="auto_const" and another attribute string="abc" (and it’s from the unique buff pool, not a string created by regex matching).
